headline.main: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL

byline.original: By Sandra Gardner SOME parents who have been accused of molesting their children say they are victims of a new style of child-custody war - one in which vengeful former spouses charge them with sexually abusing their children as a way to eliminate visitation or gain sole custody.   ''That's what you get in South Jersey, when you get a divorce, you get charged with sex abuse,'' said Margaret E. Allen of Burlington City.   Miss Allen is the co-founder of the New Jersey chapter of VOCAL (Victims of Child Abuse Laws) and the fiancee of Christopher Clauss, who was arrested and charged with molesting his then 2 1/2-year-old daughter on May 4, 1984. (The final divorce decree was granted May 14.) Mr. Clauss was later found not guilty in a Burlington County trial.   Miss Allen said that the charges against Mr. Clauss had stemmed from visitation difficulties with his former wife.   ''And you automatically lose your visitation rights,'' she said, ''and that's the way you lose custody, when you're charged with this.''   Miss Allen said that 90 percent of the 76 members of New Jersey VOCAL were involved in custody or visitation battles, had recently become involved with a new partner, or both. The chapter, formed in February 1985, was patterned after a group in Minnesota (there are reportedly 65 chapters in the country).   The New Jersey group is mostly male, but does include a few women accused of molestation and girlfriends and wives of men in the group. (Nearly all have been charged with abusing their own children, but some have been accused of molesting children they live with.) Miss Allen said that the state Department of Human Services' Division of Youth and Family Services, whose mandate is to protect children, did not follow proper procedure in investigations.   The division's actions, Mr. Clauss said, ''smack of Nazi Germany in 1933 and the McCarthy era.''   Geoffrey S. Perselay, the acting Human Services Commissioner, said of VOCAL: ''I'll quote from Shakespeare: 'Thou dost protest too much.' ''   ''There is a big difference,'' he said, ''between being 'not guilty' and being found 'not guilty' by a court, with the limitations on testimony. For example, the ability of a 2-year-old child, often your best witness, to express itself as to what occurred.''   ''It's frustrating as hell to sit here,'' he said, ''cloaked in confidentiality, being under court order not to disclose particular facts of a case, with no opportunity to defend ourselves. It's difficult enough to prosecute these cases and protect children, and then you have a group like this, trying to detract focus from the children.''   Senator Catherine A. Costa, Democrat of the Seventh District (parts of Burlington and Camden Counties), who has been meeting with members of VOCAL, said: ''It's a very serious situation. A lot of these people are really hurting bad. In some instances it's a means of gaining custody. It's a sad situation - extremely cruel. Full justice has to rise to the surface in cases of innocence.''   Elderly people, women with young children, the handicapped and the poor will have problems getting their food, nutrition, and health needs met when the Middlesex County Board of Social Services moves to the outskirts of New Brunswick from the downtown area, says Enrico De Gironimo, assistant coordinator of Community Outreach Program for Senior Adults, a Rutgers community mental-health agency, and a member of the central New Jersey Rainbow Coalition.   The coalition - comprising social workers, community activists and recipients of social services -has been protesting the move.   ''A lot of these people are walk-ins, or take the bus downtown,'' said Mr. De Gironimo, ''and it's part of the 'hidden agenda' of the New Brunswick gentrification effort to drive the poor out of sight.''   The lease on the social services building is held by Rutgers, which plans to take it over for its Mason Gross School of the Arts in June 1987; Rutgers, in turn, is being forced out of its present site for the school.   The recent decision to place the county's social services in a leased building on Route 27, bordering Franklin Township, was made by the county freeholders and the Board of Social Services. However, financing and decisions for the board are dictated by the freeholders, according to Mary L. Hollis, director of the Board of Social Services.   ''There will probably be some clients who will have some difficulty in getting there,'' Mrs. Hollis admitted. ''We have a considerable number of clients who walk in.''   According to Dorothy K. Power, deputy director of the Middlesex Board of Chosen Freeholders, ''there will be no hardship.''   ''It's a 3 1/2-mile trip to the edge of town,'' she said, adding, ''We could have gone to Edison or Metuchen.''   Mrs. Power said the county was considering providing a small bus to pick up clients. ''Or they could mail things in, or call,'' she said. As for putting up a building in downtown New Brunswick, Mrs. Powers said, ''It would not be commercially feasible and there would be no parking spaces for the workers and the clients.''   Quentin Smith, a community consultant for the New Brunswick Outreach Center, a private nonprofit social-service agency, and spokesman for the coalition, said that the group was investigating the possibility of a class-action suit and would also use political and ''street'' tactics to deal with the issue.   ''Since they - the city and county policy makers - are making us, the poor and minority groups, uncomfortable - we'll have to make it difficult and uncomfortable for them, in terms of pickets and boycotts,'' Mr. Smith said. ''Additionally, we're planning a political response, when the coalition organizes its October convention, in terms of strategy for the 1986 election campaigns.''   Do you know the ''New Jersey connection'' for Lillian Moller Gilbreth, Carrie Bamberger Frank Fuld, Virginia Apgar, Ruth Cheney Streeter and Fanny Brice?   You can find the answers - and a lot more about many other women (53 in all) - in ''Eastern Her Story, 1986 Engagement Calendar,'' just off the press from Planned Parenthood of Northwest New Jersey, based in Morristown.   The 125-page book is filled with biographies of famous and not-so-famous contemporary and historical women in the Eastern states who have made contributions in the arts, sciences, government and other walks of life.   Decisions on whom to include were based on representation in geography, race, ethnic group, career, past and present figures, as well as proportions of well-known women and ''finds,'' as Jeff Brand, executive director of the Planned Parenthood affiliate, put it.   The calendars, which will be sold at $8.95 to raise funds, ''were a natural, in terms of celebrating contributions made by American women, and, at the same time, producing income for a women's health organization,'' Mr. Brand said.   For those who would like to get to know their ''finds'' a bit more, ample bibliographic material is provided.   ''We need to institutionalize our concern for the young,'' says State Senator Leanna Brown, Republican of Chatham.   Mrs. Brown, whose 26th District takes in parts of Morris and Passaic Counties, proposes to accomplish this by forming a new standing Senate committee on children. She plans to introduce a resolution calling for such a committee in the next legislative meeting.   ''When you have a standing legislative committee, you have hearings and linkages of how various programs can help,'' Mrs. Brown said, explaining that bills affecting children are now assigned to many committees and often get side-tracked in the bureaucratic maze.   For instance, she cited her own bills: One deals with discrimination against families with children in rental housing, the other creates an ombudsman for children. Both measures have not progressed.   A committee on children would be part of a three-pronged approach to children's issues, said Mrs. Brown. The proposed Governor's Commission on Youth and Families (recommended by an executive children's policy committee) would function as a recommender of policies; an ombudsman would follow the proposals through, at the executive level, and the legislative committee would implement legislation on children's issues.   A new standing committee can be created by resolution or by the more complicated change in rules, which would most likely not take place until the beginning of a new session

key_3.lead_paragraph: The Government announced today that, beginning next March 1, blacks paying income tax in South Africa would no longer have to do so at higher rates than whites. With few exceptions, the Government said, the change will mean that black taxpayers will be paying less than before. The announcement was made by Finance Minister Owen Horwood in presenting the Government's annual budget to Parliament in Cape Town.

key_6.snippet: To the Editor:   In his review of Thomas Laqueur's "Making Sex" (Dec. 9), Melvin Konner questions the extent to which men and women were considered sexually identical during ancient and medieval times. To support his argument, he poses the questio...
key_6.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: In his review of Thomas Laqueur's "Making Sex" (Dec. 9), Melvin Konner questions the extent to which men and women were considered sexually identical during ancient and medieval times. To support his argument, he poses the question "Did . . . women in ancient cities [ pay ] men for sex as often as men paid women?" While I agree with much of what Dr. Konner has written, I would like to add the following point. In male-dominated societies in which women were prohibited from owning land and inheriting wealth and had little access to professions, a woman who chose or was forced to generate an income independently had only one thing to sell: herself. By the same token, a woman did not have the means to buy sexual pleasure. I suggest that the roots of female prostitution have less to do with differences between male and female sexuality and the desire for pleasure than with economic power. JANET R. SPARROW New York

headline.main: The Roots of Prostitution

key_7.snippet: WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- A changing population and a changing industrial structure are producing a persistent trend toward inequality in the distribution of income among wage and salary earners in the United States, a study published by the Labor De...
key_7.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- A changing population and a changing industrial structure are producing a persistent trend toward inequality in the distribution of income among wage and salary earners in the United States, a study published by the Labor Department has found.
key_7.abstract: Labor Dept study by P Henle finds that changing population and indus structure in US are producing persistent trend toward inequality in income distribution among wage and salary earners; trend is toward concentration of increasingly large share of avg wage and salary income among people in jobs and professions that already bring higher pay; unlike most studies of income, which examine family earnings, Henle study examines only money earnings of male workers; using unpublished data from Census Bur, study finds that from '58-70 the share of aggregate wage and salary income earned by lowest 5th of male workers declined to 4.60% from 5.10%; at same time, share of highest 5th of male wage and salary earners rose to 40.55% from 38.15%; Henle, in telephone int, says trend reflects tendency in econ to produce more higher-paying jobs without reducing number of lower-paid workers; comments on some factors; suggests Govt could ameliorate problem through manpower training and antidiscrimination and other programs to 'open way for individuals to advance up earnings ladder'; study findings reptd in Labor Dept Monthly Labor Rev

headline.main: Study Finds Incomes More Unequal; STUDY OF INCOME FINDS GAP GROWS

key_7.snippet: At a time when consumption is less conspicuous than it used to be, today's sure-fire clue to status is not what's being worn but what isn't. A New Yorker realized that one cold and rainy day this week when he started to look for a luncheon guest's...
key_7.lead_paragraph: At a time when consumption is less conspicuous than it used to be, today's sure-fire clue to status is not what's being worn but what isn't. A New Yorker realized that one cold and rainy day this week when he started to look for a luncheon guest's topcoat. There wasn't one -- because said luncheon guest had a limo waiting outside. But of course! The limo waiting outside explains why some women still wear high heels long after the rest of femalekind has descended to Nikes. Why they carry purses just big enough for a lipstick, handkerchief, a few bills and a credit card. Why they and their male counterparts forgo raingear. They need only walk the several paces from curb to restaurant door; they can leave their bags and briefcases in the back seat; and wherever there's a chauffeur-driven car there's sure to be a doorman with an umbrella. To spot a healthy income or healthy bank account, then, look for less. It's more.

headline.main: Topics of The Times; Seeking Status

key_7.snippet: To the Editor:    You call the increase in the number of single women with children ''troubling'' (''The Changing American Family,'' editorial, May 18).     Yes, the increase in the number of unplanned children born to low-  and moderate-income wo...
key_7.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: You call the increase in the number of single women with children ''troubling'' (''The Changing American Family,'' editorial, May 18). Yes, the increase in the number of unplanned children born to low- and moderate-income women and girls whose male partners make minimal or no contribution to their children's upbringing may be cause for concern. But doesn't the term ''single mothers'' also include professional women who choose to get pregnant and raise their kids, and women who can afford to adopt children?
key_7.abstract: Amy J Weinblatt letter on May 18 editorial on decline of nuclear family notes that term 'single mother' includes professional women who choose to raise child on their own

key_9.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''More Men's Teams Benched as Colleges Level the Field'' (front page, May 9), about the effort to achieve athletic equality for women's teams: A larger issue is how much should a college invest in athletics given its primary mission. key_9.snippet: The Census Bureau set the White House aglow this week when it reported that in 1996 median income rose for the second consecutive year while black and Hispanic poverty rates fell. President Clinton said the report proved that his economic policies...
key_9.lead_paragraph: The Census Bureau set the White House aglow this week when it reported that in 1996 median income rose for the second consecutive year while black and Hispanic poverty rates fell. President Clinton said the report proved that his economic policies were working and that the middle class was finally on the rise. But a deeper look at the census report finds a gloomier perspective -- the middle class is not doing very well and the poor are falling further behind. The backdrop for the report is an economy that has steadily recovered since 1991 and is growing at a healthy 3 percent a year. Unemployment has dropped below 5 percent to its lowest level in a quarter-century. Inflation is low and falling. Welfare rolls fell almost 10 percent last year. The minimum wage is rising. The economic landscape could not be better for middle-class families in general, and low-wage workers in particular.
key_9.abstract: Editorial notes that Census Bureau set White House aglow when it reported that in 1996 median income rose for second consecutive year while black and Hispanic proverty rates fell; disputes Pres Clinton's contention that report proves that his economic policies are working; maintains that deeper look at census report finds that middle class is not doing very well and poor are falling further behind (M)

headline.main: The Tide Is Not Lifting Everyone

key_9.snippet: For women, the pay gap between the educational haves and have-nots has widened inexorably over the last two decades. In 1980, high-school dropouts earned 57 percent as much as college graduates, but by 1998 that ratio had slid to 40 percent.     M...
key_9.lead_paragraph: For women, the pay gap between the educational haves and have-nots has widened inexorably over the last two decades. In 1980, high-school dropouts earned 57 percent as much as college graduates, but by 1998 that ratio had slid to 40 percent. Minority women are catching up in education: in 1998, almost as many Hispanic women (41 percent) and black women (56 percent) had at least some college, as did white women (60 percent).
key_9.abstract: Pay gap for women between educational haves and have-nots had widened over last two decades, in 1980, high-school dropouts earned 57 percent as much as college graduates, but by 1998 that ratio slid to 40 percent; minority women have continued to lag income, no matter what their education, but Hispanic women have done significantly better than black women; graphs (M)

headline.main: Women's Earnings: What a Difference a Degree Makes
